title: 109_s2032
content:
The Public Transportation Terrorism Prevention Act of 2005 includes sections on security assessments, grants, intelligence sharing, research, reporting requirements, and authorization of appropriations. The Act may be cited as the "Public Transportation Terrorism Prevention Act of 2005". Congress finds that public transportation systems worldwide have been targeted by terrorist attacks, resulting in numerous casualties. In the United States, 5,800 public transportation agencies serve 14,000,000 people daily. Safe and secure public transportation is crucial for the economy and national events. The Federal Transit Administration has invested $74.9 billion since 1992 in system improvements. Additionally, $18.1 billion was allocated from 2002 to 2005 to protect the aviation system and its passengers. The Federal Government has allocated $250,000,000 in fiscal years 2003 through 2005 for public transportation security improvements, highlighting the urgent need for significant investment in this area. The Federal Government allocated $250,000,000 in fiscal years 2003 through 2005 for public transportation security improvements to mitigate threats against the Nation's public transportation systems. SEC. 3. SECURITY ASSESSMENTS. The Federal Transit Administration must submit public transportation security assessments to the Secretary of Homeland Security within 30 days of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary will review and enhance these assessments by July 31, 2006, and use them to allocate grant funds unless otherwise notified. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish security improvement priorities for public transportation agencies by September 30, 2006, based on security assessments received. Updates to security assessments will be conducted annually starting from July 31, 2007. The Secretary of Homeland Security conducts security assessments for public transportation agencies at risk of terrorist attacks to develop security guidelines and strategies to minimize threats and maximize mitigation efforts. Security assessments for bus and rural public transportation systems must be completed by July 31, 2006. The Secretary of Homeland Security conducts security assessments for local bus-only and selected public transportation systems receiving funds under section 5311 of title 49, United States Code. SEC. 4. SECURITY ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Secretary of Homeland Security awards grants to public transportation agencies for capital security improvements, including tunnel protection systems, perimeter protection systems, critical operations control systems, detection systems, surveillance equipment, communications equipment, emergency response equipment, fire suppression, and decontamination equipment, and global positioning or automated vehicle locator. The Secretary of Homeland Security awards grants for capital security improvements such as tunnel protection systems, perimeter protection systems, critical operations control systems, detection systems, surveillance equipment, communications equipment, emergency response equipment, fire suppression, decontamination equipment, global positioning or automated vehicle locator systems, evacuation improvements, and other security enhancements. Grants are also provided for operational security improvements, including security training for public transportation employees, live or simulated drills, and other security measures. The Secretary of Homeland Security awards grants for various security improvements, including drills, public awareness campaigns, canine patrols, overtime reimbursement for security personnel during events, and other identified security enhancements. Congressional notification is required before grant awards. Public transportation agencies receiving grants must appoint a security coordinator, develop a maintenance plan for purchased equipment, and report annually on grant fund usage to the Department of Homeland Security. Grant funds must be used for specified security purposes, or they must be returned if misspent. If grant funds are not used for specified security purposes, the grantee must return the amount to the Treasury of the United States. SEC. 5. INTELLIGENCE SHARING. The Secretary of Homeland Security ensures timely notification of terrorist threats to public transportation assets. Financial assistance is provided for the Information Sharing and Analysis Center for Public Transportation to protect critical infrastructure. Public transportation agencies must participate as determined by the Secretary. The Secretary of Homeland Security requires public transportation agencies at risk of terrorist attacks to join the ISAC for free, while encouraging others to participate as well. SEC. 6. RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT, AND DEMONSTRATION GRANTS. The Secretary of Homeland Security, with the Federal Transit Administration, will award grants for research and demonstration of technologies to reduce terrorist threats on public transportation systems. Funds can be used for various research purposes, including detection systems and imaging technologies. Reporting requirements apply to grant recipients. Each grant recipient must report annually to the Department of Homeland Security on fund usage. If funds are misused, they must be returned to the Treasury of the United States. SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Each grant recipient must report annually to the Department of Homeland Security on fund usage, with misused funds required to be returned to the Treasury of the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a semi-annual report to Congress by March 31 and September 30 each year. The report should include information on the implementation of specific provisions, funds appropriated for sections 3 through 6, and unexpended funds. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit an annual report to Governors by March 31 detailing the grant funds distributed to public transportation agencies and their use. The report aims to provide information on unexpended or obligated funds and the state of public transportation security in the United States. Authorization of Appropriations:
- $2,370,000,000 for Capital Security Assistance Program in fiscal year 2007
- $534,000,000 for fiscal year 2007, $333,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, and $133,000,000 for fiscal year 2009 for Operational Security Assistance Program
- Appropriation for Intelligence and Research programs
Sunset Provision in Section 9. The authority to make grants under this Act will expire on October 1, 2009.
